quote: All hands, this is the captain.   The sun in the Delos system is   undergoing large-scale magnetic   field changes, producing violent,   gigantic flares.
We will be studying this star   at close range. Even though we   will be running with full   deflectors, the closeness of the   event and its severity are going   to create problems.

Intense magnetic fields have a   disruptive effect on electrical   systems. We can therefore expect   an interruption of communications,   and potential temporary loss of   other systems. As a precaution,   we are now going to Yellow   Alert...
Stay sharp, everyone.
Engineering, this is Ops. Bring   all systems on line and direct   full power to the shields.
All sections secure.
Lieutenant La Forge?
Course set.
Half impulse.
Half impulse, aye.
On Main Viewer.
Mask out the photosphere.
Magnify. Quadrant one-seven,   sector four-zero-three.
I've never seen anything like   this before. The violence of   these eruptions is awesome.
And humbling, Number One.
Reading an unusual number of   sunspots and eruptive prominences,   sir. The magnetic field is   extremely irregular.
Captain, deflectors are being hit   by a huge burst of X-rays.
Wow -- look!       Sir, my console seems to be   overloading.
The X-ray burst is disrupting   systems, Captain. I'm adjusting   deflectors to compensate.
Increase power to forward deflectors.
Status report.
All systems operational, sir.
Captain. The level of tension   on the ship is mounting.
Understandable. Data?
If we are to investigate this   unusual solar activity -- we must   get closer.
Mister La Forge, move us closer.
We'll be pushing our deflectors   to the limit, but we'll get a good   look at this phenomenon.
Captain, I have intercepted what   seems to be a distress signal.
Let me hear it.
This...  -- this is   ...  -- on the freighter   Sanction...  ... and   unable to...  .... Need   help.
The transmission is from a   freighter in orbit around the   fourth planet of the system.   However, the receiving station   is on the third planet.
Open hailing frequency.
Hailing frequencies open.
Unidentified freighter, this is   the USS Enterprise. May we be   of assistance?
Whoever you are, YES!    .... cannot maintain...    ... if you can help...
Can't you enhance the image?
Too much interference.
Set a course to intersect with   the freighter. Warp two.
Aye, sir.
Maintain Yellow Alert.
Can't control...  ... ship   is losing orbit...  ...   heading into atmosphere...   without help, we'll burn up.
It is a freighter -- very old.
Captain, our sensors are being   severely affected by the sun   flares.
Helm -- get us in as close as   possible to the freighter's   orbit.
Aye, sir.
There are six life forms aboard   the freighter.
Captain, the freighter's orbit   is decaying.
How long until it loses integrity?
A matter of minutes.
(he touches his     arm-panel)   Unidentified freighter, this is   the USS Enterprise.
Enterprise, this is the Aurelian   freighter... Sanction.
Put this on the Main Viewer.
The visual transmission is still   breaking up.
Freighter, this is the Enterprise.   What is your situation?
Get us off here.
Please -- help us.

This is the Enterprise -- with   all this interference it is   difficult to copy your   transmission -- if you all talk   at once... it is impossible. Now   -- please -- say again. What is   your situation?
I am T'Jon -- the captain of the   Sanction.
At last.       How can we help?

We have lost -- I don't know...   something -- and I am no longer   able to maintain this orbit, nor   am I able to use main thrusters.   Everything's just kind of... you   know... dead, I guess. It's   all... you know... shut down.
That's very vague. What's the   computer analysis?
The computer's not working very   well.
Data... can you tap into their   computer and clarify the   situation?
I will attempt it.
Captain, the tractor beam is   available, if you want it.
At least we can pull them out of   orbit before they enter the   atmosphere.
Yes. Captain T'Jon -- we are   going to lock on our tractor beam   and pull you out of orbit.
Hey -- that's great.
The solar flares are interfering   with the tractor beam, Captain.   I am unable to lock on.
Captain, the freighter's orbit   continues to deteriorate.
Captain T'Jon, we are unable to   attach our tractor beam because   of the intense solar activity.
I understand.       Thanks for trying.
Captain, I have determined what   is malfunctioning on the   freighter.
Enterprise to Sanction. We have   analyzed your problem.
Great.
Your ship's design uses an   electromagnetic coil to constrict   the exhaust flow. That coil is   misaligned.
Have you the necessary tools to   realign the coil?
I don't think so.
Captain, I believe we can provide   the freighter with a temporary   substitute. Ship's stores contain   a coil of the proper type.
Can we beam it over?
Yes.
Captain T'Jon, we will beam over   a replacement coil.
That's great... and that will fix   us up?
Well, once it's installed.
Right.       ... And how do we do that?
What's the matter with these   people? How can he be the captain   of the vessel and be ignorant of   its simplest functions?
If this weren't so serious it   would make you laugh.
Captain T'Jon -- how long have   you been in command of the   freighter?
Seven years. This is my   twenty-sixth voyage to Brekka.
And you don't know how to align   a control coil?
It's never come up.
Is there anyone on board who can   do it?
Hold on a minute... I'll ask.
Sorry -- nobody here knows   anything about it.
I'll beam over with a team.
Captain -- I strongly recommend   against anyone from this ship   beaming over. The solar   interference is too great.
The freighter has entered the   planet's atmosphere.   Disintegration is imminent.
We are running out of options.
(nods to Tasha and     Riker)   Let's get them off there.
Captain T'Jon. Prepare to beam   over.
If you think that's best.
Unless you have another option   -- yes, I "think that's best."
Whatever you say.
I can't maintain a positive lock.
An unusual E-M burst. Readings   off scale.
Freighter Sanction, this is the   Enterprise. We are having   difficulty getting a fix.
Have them go to their own   Transporter Room. It will be   tricky, but perhaps I can link   the two transporters in series   and get them over with the   increased power.
It's worth a try.       Captain T'Jon -- go immediately   to your Transporter Room.   Contact me from there.
Right, Enterprise -- we'll call   you from there... but, if you   can't get us with your   transporter, what makes you think   ours will do the job?
I'm going to interconnect them.
I didn't know you could do that.
Hurry -- we're running out of   time.
We're on the way.
I don't think they're going to   make it.
Captain T'Jon doesn't seem to   care one way or the other.
Worf -- how much time do we have?
One minute, twenty-eight seconds.
Captain T'Jon -- are you there?
Yeah. We're in the transporter   room.
Great. Activate your transporter.   Set coordinates nine -- seven --   zero -- three... mark two...   six... eight.
Did you say... two -- eight --   six... or eight -- eight -- six.
(frustrated almost to     the point of anger)   TWO -- SIX -- EIGHT.
Got it.
The hull temperature of the   freighter is passing three   thousand degrees.
What's the holdup, Number One?
We are establishing the link now.
We are ready.
Then all six of you get on the   transporter platform -- on my   signal, energize.
I've got their initial transporter   signal. Interlock complete.       Energize on my mark. Four --   three -- two -- one -- energize.
Did you get them off?
No. They stayed on the freighter   -- and sent their cargo.
Cargo!? Are those people crazy?       What could possibly be that   important?
Sir -- the freighter is   disintegrating.
Captain, the freighter is entering   the atmosphere. Her hull   temperature is building.
Number One -- I don't understand   these people. Their lives are   in danger and they're sending over   cargo?
Unbelievable.
We're losing the freighter.   You've got to beam those people   over now.
Clear that cargo. Beam it to a   hold.
Aye, sir.
Freighter Sanction... this is the   Enterprise, get on the transporter   pad and...       Forget it. Just lock on to any   life forms you can find and get   them over.
Trying, sir.
The freighter is going down.
Transporter Room! You're out of   time.
Reading six life forms...       But I can't get a solid lock.
We've no choice. Energize.
You said SIX - where are...       ... the other two?
The lock didn't hold, sir.
Re-establish.
It's too late.
Number One!?
scene: 37A  INT. MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON MAIN VIEWER (OPTICAL)
location: MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON MAIN VIEWER

quote: Two are lost, sir. But we saved   four.
I am Commander William Riker of   the USS Enterprise.       I'm sorry. We were unable to   rescue the other two.
Were they with you...    (then indicating the     other pair)   ... or with you?
With us.
We did everything we could, if   you had come instead of the cargo,   you could have all made it.
The cargo... Where is it?
You did save it, didn't you?
Yes, we did. It's in one of our   cargo holds. You act like it's   more important than your comrades.
May we see it?
Thank you. It's just we thought   we had lost it.
Careful with your choice of words,   T'Jon. It's ours, not yours.
We paid a fair price for it!
You offered a fair price, but we   have not received it.
You accepted our goods in trade!
Then where are they? Tell me!
That's not our problem!
No more than the barrel is your   property. It's as simple as this.   The goods were never delivered;   they were destroyed with your   ship.
Hence the deal was incomplete;   hence possession of the Felicium   remains ours!
We need it.
Commander, I request you transport   my associate --       -- and myself down to our planet,   with our merchandise.
Yes, get them out of here! But   the barrel stays.
There's no reasoning with you.
Langor, you expect too much from   them. You always have and you   are always disappointed.    (then to T'Jon with a     hard edge)   You didn't pay -- so it's not   yours.
Damn you, Sobi --
Stop this! Now!
Security to Cargo Bay Eleven!
Behave yourselves, Gentlemen.
Escort our "visitors" to the   Observation Lounge.
A natural electrical charge... ?
Formidable.
Yes, and a difficult weapon to   confiscate.
We have to resolve this. There   isn't much time.
What can you offer?
Everything we had went down with   the Sanction.
Then it is going to be difficult   to accommodate you.
Solar flares are increasing in   magnitude, sir. Deflectors are   shaky, but holding.
Maintain.       And our rather combative guests,   Number One?
Waiting for you in the   Observation Lounge, sir.
Data, what can you tell me about   the inhabitants of this system?

Not very much, sir. The only   recorded contact with the Delos   system was over two hundred years   ago. A scout ship reported two   inhabited planets, both   technologically just on the edge   of acquiring space travel.
Odd that in two centuries, neither   civilization advanced further.
Sir, I find it strange that none   of our visitors feel much remorse   about the two freighter passengers   who perished... yet their barrel   of cargo is a source of great   anxiety to them.
Yes, let us pay a call and get   some answers. Counselor, Number   One, Mister Data...
Captain, may I present Sobi and   Langor from the planet Brekka,   which we are now orbiting. And   T'Jon and Romas... from the   neighboring planet, Ornara.
I am sorry we could not save your   ship.
You could have repaired it.
Yes.
We have only two left. Neither   works. They are critical to our   survival. Could you fix them?
Mister Data?
Our computer downloaded the   specifications for the magnetic   coils the freighters depend on,   sir. Assuming the malfunction   is similar... suitable   replacements can be fabricated.
Instruct Engineering to proceed.
Aye, sir.
Now, as for our cargo...
Our cargo, Captain.
Wrong, Sobi --
My first officer has said   ownership of the cargo is in   dispute. This is a question which   must be settled by whatever legal   mechanisms exist between your   societies.
Captain Picard, you don't   understand. This is a matter of   life and death.
Why is that? What is the cargo?
Medicine.
Indeed.
Our home planet is in desperate   need, Captain. Ornara suffers   from a lethal plague.
The cargo you have impounded   represents the only hope of life   for our people.
Is that right?
Yes.
You must think us heartless   brutes, Captain, but look at our   side of it. The plant which   yields the medicine Felicium grows   only in remote areas of our home   planet Brekka.
It must be painstakingly   cultivated, harvested, and   purified... a complex and   expensive process.
That single shipment of Felicium   represents an enormous investment.   We can't just give it away!
We paid for it.       We are asking only for what is   ours.
That is your viewpoint. Ours,   of course, differs.
You are going to hold to that   position.
I am constrained to abide by the   terms of our agreement.
Then you condemn us to death!
Romas --
You disgust me! If you saw the   suffering the plague has brought,   would you still be so heartless?
We are going to get to find out,   when you see what the plague does   to us.
Romas -- you and T'Jon carry the   disease?
Yes. Every Ornaran does.
Then you may have brought it   aboard my ship!       Was there a medical scan during   transport?
Unverified -- the solar flares may   have caused a malfunction in the   biofilters --
Red Alert! Medical emergency --   decks twelve and thirteen. Doctor   Crusher to the Observation Lounge   immediately!
You find us well, I trust?
As far as I can tell. Your   physiology is somewhat different   but I detect no dangerous virus   or bacteria.
I assure you we are in perfect   health.
We're not! We need our medicine.
Our medicine.
We paid for it -- it's ours now!
Enough!
Of course you are right, Doctor.   Could we leave now?
I see no reason why not.       Escort them to their quarters.
Captain, could I talk with you   please... in private.
Not right now.
What have you learned?
The Brekkians are free of   infection. The Ornarans have all   the symptoms of a disease -- but   I can't find a cause.
Perhaps the transporter filtered   it out when they were beamed   aboard?
There's no record of it. Then   again, the solar flare activity   may have caused a transporter   malfunction.
Are they going to die?
The physiology is somewhat   different from ours, so I need   to check further, but... my   instinct says no.
Do you think we are in danger from   this plague?
Again, I don't think so, but I   need more time to know for sure.
There are some missing pieces to   the puzzle, don't you feel that   too?
What's missing here is a little   humanity.
Are we losing our professional   detachment, Doctor?
Perhaps. As Captain, I think you   should know that I am developing   a very active dislike of the   Brekkians.
Understandable.
Captain, you must give us back   our cargo.
I can't do that.
Why not? It belongs to us.
And the Brekkians insist it is   theirs.
They lie!
Maybe so, but it's not for me to   decide.
We need some now... NOW! I don't   care if it's your 'decision' or   not... get us some!
Captain, what's happening to us,   is happening to thousands more   on Ornara. Please understand the   magnitude of the problem.
Your people don't need it --    (indicating the     Brekkians)   -- they don't need it... our   people do!
If you don't give it to us, you   will be party to murder... not   only us, but an entire   civilization!
Sorry, I did not mean to insult   you. I'm feeling very shaky.
We cannot hold out much longer!
No, Captain -- I think they should   have it. They believe it will   help them. That in itself might   control their symptoms.
I'll talk with the Brekkians.
Thank you, Captain. I appreciate   anything you can do.
May I say, Captain, how impressed   we are with your ship and its   facilities.
Thank you.
And its crew. Everyone is so   efficient and professional.
I am glad you are comfortable.   I've come to seek your agreement   to an Ornaran request.
We cannot --
Wait. Let the Captain speak.   We want to be reasonable.
The Ornarans are quite ill and   are insistent that they need   Felicium.
That is not surprising.
Then would you object to allowing   them enough Felicium for their   immediate needs?
Captain, we Brekkians are in   business -- we are not in the   habit of giving away what has not   been paid for.
You would let them die rather than   share the medicine?
We want to be fair, Captain. We   agree to permitting them two   dosages for immediate use.
No charge.
I'll have our medical officer   handle it.
I trust you won't mind if we are   present while you open the cargo,   Captain.
Point-zero-one milliliters is the   proper individual dosage.
A very potent substance.
We've perfected our distillation   process over the years. In my   grandfather's day, the same amount   of Felicium would have filled five   rooms this size, Captain.
No doubt you have applied your   technology from other industries   to the refinement of this product.
We have no other industry.
None at all?
We don't need any. The Ornarans   provide us everything we need --   in exchange for this.
Fascinating. Your society   dedicated exclusively to the   production of a single product.
A product for which you have no   use for, but which the Ornarans   can't live without.
One of the little ironies of life,   Captain.
But one we'd be fools not to take   advantage of. It is mutually   beneficial.
The Ornarans provide us with the   necessities of life and we provide   them with the necessities of   living. It is a fair exchange.
A most interesting relationship.
Excuse me... I'll take this to   Sickbay.
Can I help?
No.
Hurry up!
You are feeling better?
Yes. Thank you. I'm fine now.
Report, Doctor Crusher.
I may not know Felicium's full   effect on Ornaran physiology.   But I know how to interpret   physical reactions.
Are the Ornarans recovering?
Both T'Jon and Romas are fine...   in fact, too fine.       Felicium is a narcotic.
Then T'Jon, Romas -- indeed every   Ornaran --
-- is a drug addict.
It's a fascinating little tale   we've run into of disease -- rescue   -- commerce -- and interdependence   between two worlds.
You have piqued my interest,   Number One -- please continue.
Mister Data.

Beginning several thousand years   ago, the two worlds took different   paths. Ornara became technically   sophisticated, Brekka did not.   Then two hundred years ago Ornara   was stricken by a devastating   plague.
Their advanced technology could   offer no solution.
Somehow, and there is limited   information on this point, the   cure was found in a plant which   is indigenous to only Brekka, and   which resisted all attempts at   cultivation on Ornara.
In any case a trading situation   quickly developed, which still   exists.
The Ornarans acquire the Felicium   from the Brekkians, and in   exchange, the Ornarans provide   the Brekkians with foods and   staples.
A nice arrangement for the   Brekkians.
And for the Ornarans -- without   the medicine they would all die.

No they wouldn't. Captain, here   are the results of my analysis.   Felicium is definitely a powerful   and addictive narcotic. What's   more, despite what the Ornarans   have been saying, it's not a   medicine. It was a medicine, and   it did cure the plague, two   hundred years ago.
And they no longer need it.
The plague is irrelevant now: it   doesn't exist... and it's not   going to recur.
The Ornarans have no medical need   for Felicium.
No, but their physical and   psychological need is very real.
What are you going to do?
Based on what we know so far...   there is nothing I can do.
And you don't think drug addiction   and exploitation is sufficient   cause?
This situation has existed for   a very long time. Those two   societies are intertwined in a   symbiotic relationship.
With one society profiting at the   expense of the other.
That's how you see it.
I can synthesize a non-addictive   substitute which will ease their   withdrawal symptoms.
No. We can't do that either.
I know this. You can't let them   have the Felicium.
Why? Because it goes against our   moral sensibilities? Our mission   is not to force Federation or   Earth values on others in the   galaxy.
In this case... you're wrong,   Captain. One hundred percent   wrong.
Captain, I am receiving a call   from Ornara.
Patch it in here.
The signal's ragged, but I think   I can put it on the Viewscreen.
I am Margan. Are my people on   board your ship?
Some of them, yes.
May I speak with them?

Yes.       Lieutenant Yar, have the Ornarans   brought in... no, wait, I don't   want them to have access to the   bridge.       We will contact you in a few   minutes.       I will take this in the guest   quarters.
I can understand how this could   happen to the Ornarans... What   I can't understand is why anyone   would voluntarily become dependent   upon a chemical.
Yet, the voluntary addiction to   drugs is a recurrent theme in many   cultures.
As in the twenty-first century...   when Earth governments used   narcotics to control the military.
Or look at the twentieth century.   The dangers of drug abuse were   well known, yet their use was   commonplace.
Why?
That is what I do not understand.
No one wants to become dependent.   That happens later.
But it does happen. So why do   people even start?
Oh, lots of reasons... My home   planet was a place of great   poverty and violence. For some,   the only escape was through drugs.
I fail to comprehend how a   chemical substance can provide   an escape.
It doesn't. But it makes you   think it does.       You have to understand -- drugs   can make you feel good.
They put you on top of the world.   You're happy... Sure of yourself.   In control. A lot of people never   feel that otherwise.
But it is artificial.

It doesn't feel artificial. It   feels natural, good, and mind   expanding.       Until the drug wears off. Then   you pay the price. Once you come   down, you're lower than when you   started. So you take the drug   again -- and it kicks you back   up. But not as high this time.
So you take more.
But each peak gets lower and   the valleys get deeper. Before   you know it -- you're taking the   drug not to feel good but to keep   from feeling bad.
And that's the trap.
You think the drug expands your   universe -- but it actually   shrinks it. Shrinks it to where   you and the drug are all that's   left.
Pretty soon, all you care about   is getting your next dosage.   You'll lie, cheat, steal --   anything to get that fix.
Certainly by then you would   realize the danger.
That's the worst of it. You don't   care. The drug is your salvation   -- your survival. Nothing else   is important.
I guess I just don't understand.
Wesley, I hope you never do.
Lieutenant Yar, we are ready in   the guest quarters.
T'Jon. Have you got it?
Well, it's here, but...
You've got to get it to us.   T'Jon... please... We're dying   here. You don't know... this is   the worst it's ever been.
I'm doing everything I can.   See... what happened was...
Stop. I can't listen. T'Jon...   we need the medicine. So, many   people... so much suffering.   You've got to get it to us. I   can't... I can't go on. Help,   T'Jon... please.
I'm sorry.
Take us to our planet - leave us   there with our medicine or this   person dies.

Don't you see -- I have no choice.   We were sent to bring back the   Felicium. The suffering on my   planet is too great. People are   dying. It doesn't matter any more   whether we are entitled to the   Felicium... we have to have it.
Let him go.
Take us there now -- or give us   a shuttle -- but we must have the   medicine... if you refuse, this   person dies.
I will not be coerced.
I'll do it. I'll kill him.
No you won't. You're not a killer   and neither am I.
Help us... please... help us.
I'm not sure that I can.
Captain Picard, we couldn't help   overhearing. Could I see you for   a moment?
Come with me, Doctor. This could   be interesting.
We have thought about this a great   deal.
Both of us feel deeply about what   is happening on Ornara.
Although this is going to cause   hardship to us and to our people,   we have decided to give the   Felicium to them.
They can pay for it when they are   able.
We don't want to cause any   suffering.
I wonder why I expected this.
Pardon?
It's the other shoe.
The Ornarans are not aware, are   they?
Of what?
That the plague which nearly   destroyed Ornara... infected your   world as well.
You don't know that for sure.
It had to.
But somehow, one of your ancestors   realized that your desire for the   drug continued after the disease   had been cured. They made the   connection and were able to end   their addiction.

But these same wonderful people   also realized that their neighbors   never found out. Their need for   the drug grew to the point it is   now. Your sole source of support   comes from providing the narcotic.
And the refinement process of   which you are so proud was a way   to make Felicium even more   addicting... and tighten your   grip on the Ornarans even further.
Are you going to tell them?

No. I can't tell them. You see,   I am bound by the rules of the   United Federation of Planets,   which say I am not to interfere   in other worlds, other cultures.   To tell them any of this would   be interfering and would violate   the Prime Directive.
You're talking to us about it...
Telling you things you already   know... which changes nothing.
Jean-Luc. I can synthesize   something which will alleviate   their suffering and make   withdrawal painless.
That won't be necessary, because   if I understand the captain, he   is going to allow the Ornarans   to have the Felicium.
Yes, I am.

You can't do that. Some things   go beyond words on a page. These   Brekkians have knowingly enslaved   others. They have caused untold   suffering and hardship, just so   their pitiful lives could be   easier. At least don't give the   Ornarans more drugs.
It is not for me to make any of   these decisions.
You are absolutely right, Captain.
Captain, we've arrived at Ornara   and assumed standard orbit.
Acknowledged. Thank you.
Forgive me for doing what I must.       I'm beaming you down to your   world... with your Felicium.
Good. I knew it would work out   this way.
You've made the only humanitarian   decision, Captain.
Langor and I will beam down to   Ornara with you.
We'll work out payment terms for   the Felicium.
On behalf of my people, I extend   thanks for your benevolent   attitude.
And I also thank you, Captain,   for doing the right thing.
Your gift of these coils will   ensure that our freighters will   continue to work.
No.
No.
I will not supply you with spare   parts for your freighters. If   you want them repaired, you'll   have to do that yourself.
In a short time our freighters   will be inoperable.
Quite possibly.
But we depend on those freighters!   We must have those parts.
If you withhold those coils,   you're disrupting the stability   of both our planets --
-- and interfering with a trade   arrangement that has lasted for   generations! What of this Prime   Directive of yours?
Nothing in the Prime Directive   compels me to help you.
You're an executioner, Captain.   You want our world to perish.
No. That's not what I want.
But without our freighters, there   will be no more shipments of   Felicium! We will die!
You must trust in yourselves.   There are... other options.
And you must understand that my   oath as a Starfleet officer gives   me no choice in the matter.
Transporter Room. Lock onto our   guests and their cargo and beam   them down to Ornara.
Captain, I hope you realize what   you've done to us.
Of that, you can be sure.       Good luck.
When the Felicium runs out, the   people of Ornara will suffer   horrible withdrawal pains.
No doubt.
We could have made their burden   easier.
Only in the short run. Painful   as it will be, the people of   Ornara -- and the people of Brekka   -- must shape their own destinies.
It sounds so... heartless.
Doctor, it was not an easy   decision.
I just hope it was the right one.
Mister La Forge, take us out of   orbit.
Aye, sir. Course laid in.
Engage.
